articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in B (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Dominant 7b5 in B (Shape: E)

## Brief Presentation
The Dominant 7b5 chord in B with E shape is a complex and dissonant chord voicing that adds tension and color to a musical piece. This chord consists of the root (B), major third (D#), diminished fifth (F), and minor seventh (A) notes.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: B
- Major Third: D#
- Diminished Fifth: F
- Minor Seventh: A

The intervals in this chord are a major third between B and D#, a diminished fifth between B and F, and a minor seventh between B and A.

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord in B with E shape is commonly found in jazz and blues genres. It imparts a sense of tension and instability due to the dissonance created by the combination of the major third and diminished fifth intervals. This chord can add a jazzy and sophisticated flavor to a musical progression or solo improvisation.

## Songs
Here are 3 songs that use the Dominant 7b5 chord in B with E shape:
1. "So What" by Miles Davis
2. "Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk
3. "All Blues" by Miles Davis
